body_content.explanation: a piece of furniture or part of a train, plane, etc. that has been designed for someone to sit on:
examples: Chairs, sofas and benches are different types of seat.
Please have/take a seat (= sit down).
A car usually has a driver's seat, a front/passenger seat and back/rear seats.
My ticket says 22D but there's already someone in (= sitting on) that seat.
Is this seat free/taken (= is anyone using it)?
Would you keep (= stop anyone else from sitting in) my seat (for me) while I go get some food?
Please stay in/keep your seats (= stay sitting down) until asked to leave.
Could I book/reserve two seats (= arrange for them to be officially kept for me) for tomorrow evening's performance?

body_content.explanation: the part of a piece of furniture or clothing on which a person sits:
examples: I've spilled some coffee on the seat of the armchair.
The seat of those trousers looks a little tight. Do you want to try a larger size?

body_content.explanation: a person's bottom (= the part of the body that you sit on):
examples: When trying out the bike, I had to stop often because my seat was sore.

body_content.explanation: an official position as a politician or member of a group of people who control something:
examples: She has a seat on the board of directors.
He is expected to lose his seat on the city council in next month's elections.
She won her seat in Parliament in 2004.
He has a very safe seat (= a position that is very unlikely to be lost in an election).

body_content.explanation: the place in an office where a particular person sits:
examples: I'm sorry - he's not in his seat right now.

body_content.explanation: a place on a course to study something:
examples: On receipt of the tuition fees, the college will issue a letter confirming your seat on the course.

body_content.explanation: a place that acts as a base or centre for an important activity:
examples: The seat of government in the US is in Washington, DC.
St Petersburg was the seat of the Russian Revolution.

body_content.explanation: the way that a person sits when riding a horse:
examples: Your security and your control of the horse depend greatly on having a good seat.

body_content.explanation: to arrange for someone to have a particular seat:
examples: The waiter greeted me with a big smile and seated us by the window.
"I'm so glad to see you!" she said, seating herself between Eleanor and Marianne.
She seemed restless but eventually seated herself beside him.
Tom seated himself opposite her and tried not to stare.
She had already seated herself behind her desk.
After some deliberation, Sara seated herself by the window.
Having looked out of the window, he returned to his desk and seated himself again.

body_content.explanation: (of a building, room, table, or vehicle) to have enough seats for the stated number of people:
examples: The new concert hall seats 1,500 people.

body_content.explanation: with enough seats for the particular number of people:
examples: a 2,000-seat theatre
